The first man says: "None of us is a truthteller."
The second man says: "At most one of us is a truthteller."
The third man says: "At most two of us are truthtellers."
...
The twelfth and last man says: "At most eleven of us are truthtellers."
Who are the liars?
 Hint: It's OK to use trial and error, however, there might exist better methods.
Hint: It's OK to use trial and error, however, there might exist better methods.
Human Solution:
If there are exactly N liars, then the last N men are truthtellers, leaving the first (12-N) men to be liars.
Therefore, N=12-N, N=6. The first 6 men are liars, and the last 6 men are truthtellers.
Response:
Let T be the (unknown) number of truthtellers among the twelve men.

Statement made by man i (i = 1,2,…,12)
“At most (i − 1) of us are truthtellers.”

This statement is true exactly when  
T ≤ (i − 1),  
and it is false exactly when  
T ≥ i.

Hence

• Man i is a truthteller  ⇔  T ≤ (i − 1)  ⇔  i ≥ T + 1.  
• Man i is a liar        ⇔  i ≤ T.

Therefore the set of truthtellers is {T+1, T+2, …, 12}; its size is 12 − T.  
But, by definition, the number of truthtellers is T itself.  
Thus  
T = 12 − T  ⇒  2T = 12  ⇒  T = 6.

Consequently

• Men 1 through 6 are liars.  
• Men 7 through 12 are truthtellers.

Checking quickly: with T = 6, man 7 says “At most 6 of us are truthtellers,” true, …, man 12 says “At most 11 of us are truthtellers,” also true; while men 1–6 each claim a bound less than 6 and therefore lie. All conditions are satisfied.

Final answer: The liars are men 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6.

Question:
Question: A man has 3 cards face down on a table.  One is a jack and two are aces.  He knows the order but you do not.  You can ask him one yes or no question, but when you do, you have to point to one of the cards.  If you point to an ace, he will tell the truth, if you point to the jack, he will randomly say yes or no.  You have to find one of the aces.
 Hint: Yes, there is always a chance you will be pointing to the jack, and that the answer will be meaningless (just a random yes/no) but there is a way to work around it.  Don't give up!
Hint: Yes, there is always a chance you will be pointing to the jack, and that the answer will be meaningless (just a random yes/no) but there is a way to work around it.  Don't give up!
Human Solution: Point to the middle card and say,  "Is the card to the right an ace?"  If the answer is yes, then the card on the right is an ace. If the answer is no, the card on the left is an ace.  This solution works because if you're pointing to an ace then he's obviously telling the truth and if you're pointing to the jack the answer doesn't matter anyway because you will pick one of the other two which are both aces.
Response:
Point to any one of the three cards – call the one you are pointing at X, and label the other two Y and Z.  
While your finger is on X, ask the man the single yes-or-no question

  “Is the card Y an ace?”

• If he answers “Yes”, turn over Y.  
• If he answers “No”, turn over Z.

Why this always works  

1. If the card you are pointing at (X) is the jack, both of the other two cards Y and Z are aces.  
   The jack answers at random, but whether it says “yes’’ or “no’’ you will turn over an ace.

2. If the card you are pointing at (X) is an ace, the answer is truthful.  
   • If Y is an ace the truthful answer is “yes’’ and you turn over Y (an ace).  
   • If Y is the jack the truthful answer is “no’’ and you turn over Z, the remaining card, which must be the second ace.

In every possible distribution of the two aces and the jack this procedure reveals an ace with certainty, using exactly one yes-or-no question while pointing at a single card.

Final answer: Point at one card, ask “Is that other specific card an ace?”; believe the reply if it comes from an ace, and whichever way he answers, the card you subsequently turn over by the above rule is guaranteed to be an ace.

Question:
Question: At a family get-together, four married couples played bridge at two different tables (4 people at each table). From the statements below determine which players were at which table and who their partner was.
1. Mrs. Johnson was partnered with her son-in-law.
2. Mr. Jones' partner was his wife's brother-in-law.
3. Mrs. Jones played against her sister.
4. Mr. Johnson played against his father-in-law.
5. Mrs. Smith's partner was her daughter.
6. Mrs. Williams partner was her grandfather.
7. Mr. Johnson's partner was a man.
 Hint: From statements 3, 5 and 6 the four couples consist of 3 generations since there is a set of sisters involved and there are grandparents present.
Hint: From statements 3, 5 and 6 the four couples consist of 3 generations since there is a set of sisters involved and there are grandparents present.
Human Solution:
From statements 3, 5 and 6 the four couples consist of 3 generations since there is a set of sisters involved and there are grandparents present.
From 2 and 3, the Jones are definitely one of the sisters, and from 6, the Williams are definitely on the 3rd generation. Looking at 1 and 4, the Johnson's are on the 2nd generation and since the Smiths have a daughter, they are on the 1st or 2nd generation. But since the Jones must be one of the sisters, the Smiths cannot fall in the 2nd generation with the Johnson's. Therefore the Smiths are the grandparents.
From 6, Mrs. Williams' partner is Mr. Smith.  From 1 and 6, Mrs. Johnston and Mrs. Williams both have male partners, therefore from 5, Mrs. Smith's partner could have only been Mrs. Jones. Which also means that Jones and Johnson are the pair of sisters.
Thus from 2, Mr. Jones is then partnered with Mr. Johnson, and from 3, Mrs Jones (who is partnered with Mrs. Smith) is playing against Mrs. Johnson (whose partner is Mr. Williams from 1).
In summation, Mr. Jones and Mr. Johnson play against Mrs. Williams and Mr Smith, while Mrs Jones and Mrs. Smith play against Mrs. Johnson and Mr. Williams.

Question:
Question: The following task involves several steps, but they are out of order.  Arrange them so that a person who follows the steps exactly can perform the task:
You have three heavy beams marked A, B, and C, and want to find out which one is the heaviest.  You also have a scale that tells you which of any two beams is heavier, but it does not give the specific weight of any beam.  In what order must you perform the following steps to determine which beam is the heaviest, and to mark it accordingly?  Assume that all three have different weights.
a)  Weigh A against B.
b)  Weigh B against C.
c)  Weigh A against C.
d)  If A is heavier, skip the next three statements.
e)  If A is heavier, skip the next four statements.
f)  If B is heavier, skip the next five statements.
g)  Mark A "heaviest."
h)  Mark B "heaviest."
i)  Mark C "heaviest."
j)  Skip the next statement.
k)  Skip the next two statements.
l)  Skip the next three statements.
m)  End.
 Hint: The first two steps are "a" and "d", in that order.
Hint: The first two steps are "a" and "d", in that order.
Human Solution:
a)  Weigh A against B.
d)  If A is heavier, skip the next three statements.
b)  Weigh B against C.
f)  If B is heavier, skip the next five statements.
k)  Skip the next two statements.
c)  Weigh A against C.
e)  If A is heavier, skip the next four statements.
i)  Mark C "heaviest."
l)  Skip the next three statements.
h)  Mark B "heaviest."
j)  Skip the next statement.
g)  Mark A "heaviest."
m)  End.
Response:
The steps can be arranged so that, no matter which beam is the heaviest, exactly one of the three marking instructions (g, h, i) is executed and the program then terminates.  
The correct linear program is:

a → d → b → f → k → c → e → i → l → h → j → g → m

1. a : Weigh A against B.  
2. d : If A is heavier, skip the next 3 statements (b, f, k).  
   • This takes us straight to c when A > B, otherwise we continue.  
3. b : (Reached only when B > A) Weigh B against C.  
4. f : If B is heavier, skip the next 5 statements (k, c, e, i, l) and go to h.  
   • Thus, when B is heaviest we mark B in step h and then end.  
5. k : (Reached only when C > B > A) Skip the next 2 statements (c, e) so that we never weigh A vs C when we already know C > B > A.  
6. c : (Reached only when A > B) Weigh A against C.  
7. e : If A is heavier, skip the next 4 statements (i, l, h, j) and go to g to mark A.  
   • Otherwise we proceed to i to mark C.  
8. i : Mark C “heaviest.”  
9. l : Skip the next 3 statements (h, j, g) so that after marking C we go straight to m.  
10. h : Mark B “heaviest.” (Reached only when B is heaviest.)  
11. j : Skip the next statement (g) so that after marking B we proceed to m.  
12. g : Mark A “heaviest.” (Reached only when A is heaviest.)  
13. m : End.

Tracing every possible ordering of weights (A > B > C, A > C > B, B > A > C, B > C > A, C > A > B, C > B > A) confirms that exactly one correct marking instruction is executed, after which the program terminates.

Final answer: a, d, b, f, k, c, e, i, l, h, j, g, m

Question:
Question: Major Steve is forming a five-person Special Task Group for the Madadian army. The group must contain one leader, two bomb-experts and two soldiers.
P, Q and R are possible bomb-experts. R, S and T are possible leaders. U, V and W are possible soldiers. Also, P and R prefers to work with each other in the same team. T prefers to work only if V works.
How many different possible Groups can Major Steve make?
 Hint: Draw it out!
Hint: Draw it out!
Human Solution:
Major Steve can make 8 different possible groups.
As 2 bomb-experts to be selected from the given 3 and also P & R prefers to work together, PR must be there in all the possible Groups. Also, T prefers to work only if V works. It doesn't mean that V won't work without T.
Hence, possible groups are:
PR - S - UV
PR - S - VW
PR - S - WU
PR - T - UV
PR - T - VW
PQ - R - UV
PQ - R - VW
PQ - R - WU
Hence,  8 different groups are possible.
Response:
Let  

• bomb–experts = {P , Q , R}  
• leaders        = {R , S , T}  
• soldiers       = {U , V , W}

Required composition of a group: 1 leader + 2 bomb-experts + 2 soldiers  
Extra conditions  
1. P and R appear together or not at all.  
2. If T is chosen, then V must also be chosen.

Step 1.  Show that P and R must both be in every feasible group.  
Suppose one of them is absent.  
– If P is absent, the only possible bomb-experts are Q and (perhaps) R.  
  • If R is also absent ⇒ only Q is left ⇒ we cannot get 2 bomb-experts.  
  • If R is present (alone) ⇒ still only one bomb-expert.  
So P cannot be absent. By symmetry R cannot be absent either.  
Hence P ∈ group and R ∈ group for every valid selection.

Thus the two bomb-expert slots already contain P, and either Q or R.

Step 2.  Case analysis on the role taken by R.

Case 1.  R is the leader.  
• Bomb-experts = P and Q.  
• No restriction involving T (T is not selected).  
• Choose 2 soldiers from {U, V, W}:  C(3,2)=3 ways.

Case 2.  R is a bomb-expert.  
The second bomb-expert is now fixed (P), so we still need a leader.

 2a.  Leader = S  
  • T is not selected ⇒ no V-condition.  
  • Soldiers: any 2 from {U, V, W}: 3 ways.

 2b.  Leader = T  
  • Because T is chosen, V must be a soldier.  
  • Soldiers therefore are {V, x} where x∈{U, W}: 2 ways.

Summary of counts  
Case 1: 3 groups  
Case 2a: 3 groups  
Case 2b: 2 groups  
Total = 3 + 3 + 2 = 8

Final answer: 8

Question:
Question: LTVX
AFHKNZ
_ _ _
What three letters fill in the blanks?
 Hint: - The title has a partial clue.
- Look down.
- They are grouped horizontally.
Hint:
- The title has a partial clue.
- Look down.
- They are grouped horizontally.
Human Solution:
E M W
The first row requires two straight lines to make. (LTVX)
The Second row requires three straight lines to make.  (AFHKNZ)
Following the pattern, the next row should have four straight lines to make, and the only letters that do that are EMW.
(Also everything has been so far in alphabetical order so it has to be "EMW", not EWM, MEW, MWE, WME, or WEM.)
Response:
Observe what the letters in each given row have in common when they are written in ordinary block capitals.

Row 1 L T V X  
Each of these letters can be drawn with exactly 2 straight-line strokes.

Row 2 A F H K N Z  
Each of these letters can be drawn with exactly 3 straight-line strokes.

The hint “look down” tells us to continue the pattern by moving to the next (lower) number of rows, that is, to the next larger number of strokes.  
So the third row must contain every capital letter that needs exactly 4 straight-line strokes, and nothing else.

Only three capital letters meet that requirement:

E (1 vertical + 3 horizontals)  
M (2 verticals + 2 diagonals)  
W (4 diagonals)

Keeping the alphabetical order used in the first two rows, the third row is

E M W

Final answer: EMW

Question:
Question: List the order in which each person finished.
Tommy Tombstone finished after Lance Lamers and Brett Brown but before Mitch Monday.
Peter Poultry finished before Daniel Dusk and Lance Lamers.
Sam Sunny finished after Peter Poultry and before Jack Jill and Harry Hills.
Keri Kernel finished after Peter Poultry, Mitch Monday and Tommy Tombstone.
Lance Lamers finished after Brett Brown and Daniel Dusk, but before Jack Jill and Mitch Monday.
Mitch Monday finished after Sam Sunny and Brett Brown.
Brett Brown finished before Jack Jill, Mitch Monday and Peter Poultry.
Daniel Dusk finished before Keri Kernel and Tommy Tombstone, but after Sam Sunny.
Jack Jill finished before Keri Kernel, Tommy Tombstone and Mitch Monday, but after Peter Poultry and Daniel Dusk.
Harry Hills finished before Mitch Monday but after Lance Lamers, Jack Jill and Tommy Tombstone.
 Hint: Figure out who could possibly be first? Work from there
Hint: Figure out who could possibly be first? Work from there
Human Solution:
1.Brett Brown
2.Peter Poultry
3.Sam Sunny
4.Daniel Dusk
5.Lance Lamers
6.Jack Jill
7.Tommy Tombstone
8.Harry Hills
9.Mitch Monday
10.Keri Kernel
Response: Final answer: Brett Brown, Peter Poultry, Sam Sunny, Daniel Dusk, Lance Lamers, Jack Jill, Tommy Tombstone, Harry Hills, Mitch Monday, Keri Kernel

Question:
Question: A prisoner sat alone in his cell staring through the bars at the six doors to the guardroom beyond them. Suddenly, there was the sound of footsteps. One guard came in through door A and a second entered through door F. They unlocked the cell door. "We shall set you free," said one of the guards, "but first you must pass through all six doors, each door once only, in the correct order. Three are entrances only and three are exits only. Door A must be followed by door B or E; B by C or E; C by D or F; D by A or F; E by B or D; and F by C or D." With that the guards left through door B. In what order must the prisoner pass through the doors?
 Hint: The prisoner must alternate exits and entrances. List the six possible orders then study the conditions to eliminate possibilities.
Hint: The prisoner must alternate exits and entrances. List the six possible orders then study the conditions to eliminate possibilities.
Human Solution:
The order is CFDABE. The guards entered through doors A and F and exited at door B. The prisoner must alternate exits and entrances. Let the unknown entrance be X. With a "_" denoting an exit door the possible orders are:
(a) _A_F_X ; (b) _F_A_X ; (c) _X_A_F ; (d) _X_F_A ; (e) _A_X_F ; (f) _F_X_A
Neither (a) nor (c) are possible since A is followed by B or E and neither leads to F. Since A can only be preceded by D, (e) and (f) are possible as DA_X_F and _F_XDA, respectively. With D used, door F can only be preceded by C to give DA_XCF and CF_XDA, respectively. Door B must occupy the remaining space in each possibility (third door is exit) so X=E but C cannot follow E in the former and for the latter, B cannot follow F. This eliminates (e) and (f). Since only D precedes A, (b) is possible as _FDA_X and (d) as _X_FDA. For (d), the exit B must occupy a "_" but cannot be followed by F, and if it is the first door, neither the C or E that must follow as X can be followed by the remaining E or C, respectively. This only leaves (b) and only C (of the possible B,C,E) can precede F as CFDA_X and B must occupy the final "_" as an exit leaving E=X. Notice that the condition that E is followed by B or D cannot be satisfied until the prisoner has completed his task and finally wins his freedom through B or D!
Response:
Because three of the six doors are “entrances only’’ and the other three are “exits only’’, a passage that uses every door once must alternate

exit  → entrance  → exit  → entrance  → exit  → entrance.       (1)

Let the six successive doors be D₁ D₂ D₃ D₄ D₅ D₆; then D₁ , D₃ , D₅ are exits and D₂ , D₄ , D₆ are entrances.

1.  Which doors are certainly entrances or exits?  
   • The guards came in through A and F, so A and F are entrances.  
   • They went out through B, so B is an exit.

   Hence               entrances : A , F , ( one more )  
                       exits     : B , ( two more ).                (2)

2.  Use the list of admissible successors

   A → B or E  B → C or E  C → D or F  
   D → A or F  E → B or D  F → C or D.                     (3)

   Observe two key facts.

   • Only D can precede A (because the only arrow ending at A is D → A).  
   • Only C can precede F (because the only arrow ending at F is C → F).

   Consequently every admissible sequence must contain the two exit-entrance
   pairs

                       … C F …  and  … D A ….                (4)

3.  Join these two pairs.

   From (3) F can be followed only by C or D; C is already used in (4), so F
   must be followed by D.  Therefore the unique string forced so far is

                       C F D A ….                            (5)

4.  Finish the chain.

   After A only B or E may follow.  Because B is an unused exit and
   E an unused entrance, place them next:

                       C F D A B E.                          (6)

   This exhausts all six doors.  Check that each consecutive pair is
   permitted by (3):

   C → F (F → C or D: here D)  
   F → D (D → A or F: here A)  
   D → A (A → B or E: here B)  
   A → B (B → C or E: here E).

   All conditions are satisfied.  Moreover, with pattern (1) the doors in
   positions 1, 3, 5 are exits (C, D, B) and those in positions 2, 4, 6 are
   entrances (F, A, E), exactly as required by (2).

Hence there is only one possible order:

Final answer: C F D A B E

Question:
Question: In a distant planet called Zlymph (pronounced: zl-i-mf) there were 6 different creatures there.
One was called Fymphy.
Another was called Lymfry.
Yet another was called Phyzygwy.
The next one was called Blympy.
Hyjyky was the name of another one.
Finally, there was the Jygzyll.
What you are trying to find out is the following things using the clues after this:
What they enjoyed to eat,
What they hated to eat,
and what planet they were originally from.
Choose from the following:
Food: Humans, other creatures, dragons, dirt from the planet, metal, and salt.
Planets: Venus, Pluto, Sun, Mercury, Jupiter, and Uranus.
CLUES!
1. The one who hates dirt from the planet was from Uranus.
2. The Blympy hates what the Jygzyll loves.
3. The one who loves humans is from a gas planet.
4. The Fymphy should be dehydrated.
5. The Lymfry hates what the Fymphy loves.
6. The one who hates humans is from Pluto.
7. The one who loves dragons is from Venus.
8. The Jygzyll hates what the Lymfry loves.
9. The Hyjyky loves what the Phyzygwy hates.
10. The Hyjyky hates what the Blympy loves.
11. The Blympy hates what the Phyzygwy loves.
12. The Jygzyll loves what the Fymphy hates.
13. The Fymphy loves an organism that is both an herbivore and a carnivore.
14. The Lymfry loves a mythical creature.
15. No human can get near the place the Blympy is from.
16. The Phyzygwy is from Mercury.
17. The Blympy loves dirt from the planet.
 Hint: Salt = dehydration
Hint: Salt = dehydration
Human Solution:
Fymphy: Loves salt (clue 4), hates humans (clue 6), and is from Pluto (clue 6).
Lymfry: Loves dragons (clue 14), Hates salt (clue 4/5), and is from Venus (7).
Blympy: Loves dirt from the planet (clue 17), hates metal, (clue 11), and is from the sun (clue 15).
Jygzyll: Loves humans (clue 12), hates dragons (clue 8), and is from Jupiter (clue 3).
Phyzygwy: Loves metal (clue 11), hates other creatures (clue 9), and is from Mercury (clue 16).
Hyjyky: Loves other creatures (clue 9), hates dirt from the planet (clue 10), and is from Uranus (clue 1).

Question:
Question: Mad Ade is once more perched outside the "Sweaty Chef Kebab Shop" waiting for it to open. He glances at his new digital watch and notices that the time and date display used 10 digits in its HH:MM:SS Month/Day format.
It was 17:59:56 09/03.
Mad Ade wondered to himself, if all ten digits 0-9 appear on the display, what is (a) the earliest, and (b) the latest date and time in the year this could happen?
Obviously he didn't work out the answer as the doors opened and his mind turned to more important things.
What would the answer be?
 Hint: There are 5 digits positions which all must be 5 or less. Use this to deduce that the first spot must be a 1.
Hint: There are 5 digits positions which all must be 5 or less. Use this to deduce that the first spot must be a 1.
Human Solution:
A, The earliest time of the year is 17:48:59 03/26
B, The latest time of the year is 17:56:43 09/28

Question:
Question: You've been placed on a course of expensive medication in which you are to take one tablet of Sildenafil and one tablet of Citrate daily. You must be careful that you take just one of each because taking more of either can have serious side effects.
Taking Sildenafil without taking Citrate, or vice versa, can also be very serious, because they must be taken together in order to be effective. In summary, you must take exactly one of the Sildenafil pills and one of the Citrate pills at one time. Therefore, you open up the Sildenafil bottle, and you tap one Sildenafil pill into your hand. You put that bottle aside and you open the Citrate bottle. You do the same, but by mistake, two Citrates fall into your hand with the Sildenafil pill.
Now, here's the problem. You weren't watching your hand as the pills fell into it, so you can't tell the Sildenafil pill apart from the two Citrate pills. The pills look identical. They are both the same size, same weight (10 micrograms), same color (Blue), same shape (perfect square), same everything, and they are not marked differently in any way.
What are you going to do? You cannot tell which pill is which, and they cost $300 a piece, so you cannot afford to throw them away and start over again. How do you get your daily dose of exactly one Sildenafil and exactly one Citrate without wasting any of the pills?
 Hint: You can cut pills in half
Hint: You can cut pills in half
Human Solution: Carefully cut each of the three pills in half, and carefully separate them into two piles, with half of each pill in each pile. You do not know which pill is which, but you are 100% sure that each of the two piles now contains two halves of Citrate and half of Sildenafil. Now go back into the Sildenafil bottle, take out a pill, cut it in half, and add one half to each stack. Now you have two stacks, each one containing two halves of Sildenafil and two halves of Citrate. Take one stack of pills today, and save the second stack for tomorrow.
Response:
1. Leave the three indistinguishable tablets (1 Sildenafil + 2 Citrates) in your hand and, from the Sildenafil bottle, take out one additional tablet whose identity you do know (it is certainly Sildenafil).  
   – You now possess 4 tablets: exactly 2 Sildenafil and 2 Citrate, even though you cannot tell which is which except for the one extra Sildenafil you have just taken.

2. With a pill‐cutter (or a clean sharp blade) cut each of the four tablets exactly in half.  
   – This gives 8 half-tablets: 4 half-Sildenafil and 4 half-Citrate.

3. Make two piles, A and B, by placing one half of every original tablet into pile A and the other half into pile B.  
   – Because each whole tablet has been split evenly, each pile receives one half of every tablet that existed.  
   – Hence each pile contains half of each of the 2 Sildenafil tablets (totaling one full Sildenafil) and half of each of the 2 Citrate tablets (totaling one full Citrate).

   Therefore   
   pile A = 1 full dose Sildenafil + 1 full dose Citrate  
   pile B = 1 full dose Sildenafil + 1 full dose Citrate

4. Swallow pile A now: that is exactly today’s required dose (one Sildenafil and one Citrate).  

5. Store pile B in a labeled container; it will serve as tomorrow’s exact dose, with no pill wasted and no risk of taking an incorrect amount.

Final answer: Add one known Sildenafil tablet, cut all four tablets in half, give each half-tablet to one of two piles; each pile then contains exactly one Sildenafil and one Citrate. Take one pile today and save the other for tomorrow, so no medication is wasted.

Question:
Question: The first chess tournament ended. Bab, Beb, Bib, Bob and Bub became good friends, and returned to their houses.
They told their wives about the tournament. Their wives were also chess players, and they decided to hold another tournament.
This time, each of the 10 players was going to play against each other player once, with an exception that no games were played between the couples. So a total of 40 games would be played.
After some days passed, they decided to have a get-together. Bub asked the other people how many matches until then they had played.
Something fun was that Bub heard 9 different answers.
How many matches until then had Mrs. Bub played?
 Hint: If you can't figure it out, draw a diagram.
Hint: If you can't figure it out, draw a diagram.
Human Solution:
Each player could play at most 8 matches, so the answers Bub heard was 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 in some order.
Assume without loss of generality that it was Bab that had played 8 matches. Then all players except Mrs. Bab must have played against Bab, and it must have been Mrs. Bab who had played no matches.
Then, assume without loss of generality that Beb had played 7 matches, and then all players except Mrs. Bab and Mrs. Beb must have played against Beb, and it must have been Mrs. Beb who had played 1 match.
Repeat this and we know that Mrs. Bub had played 4 matches.

Question:
Question: Al, Ben, Carl, and Dan live in four adjacent apartments. The apartments are set up like this:
|1|2|3|4|
with apartment 1 being the westernmost apartment and apartment 4 being the easternmost. One of the four is the landlord. Here are some facts:
1. If Carl does not live next to Ben, then Al is the landlord and he lives in apartment 1.
2. If Al lives east of Carl, then Dan is the landlord and he lives in apartment 4.
3. If Ben does not live next to Dan, then Carl is the landlord and he lives in apartment 3.
4. If Dan lives east of Al, then Ben is the landlord and he lives in apartment 2.
Who is the landlord?
 Hint: All four facts are in the form of "hypothesis and conclusion" statements. If the hypothesis of such a statement is false, the whole statement is true. If the conclusion is true, the whole statement is true. However, if the hypothesis is true and the conclusion is false, the statement is false. This means that each statement has either a false hypothesis or a true conclusion.
Hint: All four facts are in the form of "hypothesis and conclusion" statements. If the hypothesis of such a statement is false, the whole statement is true. If the conclusion is true, the whole statement is true. However, if the hypothesis is true and the conclusion is false, the statement is false. This means that each statement has either a false hypothesis or a true conclusion.
Human Solution:
Carl is the landlord.
Obviously only one conclusion is true at most. Let us suppose that all conclusions are false. This would mean that each hypothesis is also false. From facts 1 and 3, Ben lives next to both Carl and Dan, and therefore between Carl and Dan. Then either Al lives east of both Carl and Dan (contradicting fact 4) or Carl and Dan both live east of Al (contradicting fact 2.) So there must be exactly one true hypothesis, which will be paired with the one true conclusion. Obviously each of the three false conclusions is paired with a false hypothesis.
If conclusion 1 is true, then Al lives in apartment 1. But since hypothesis 4 is false, Al has to live east of Dan. So this cannot be right.
If conclusion 2 is true, then Dan lives in apartment 4. But since hypothesis 4 is false, Al must live east of Dan. So this cannot be right, either.
If conclusion 4 is true, Ben lives in apartment 2. Then, since hypotheses 1 and 3 are false, Ben lives between Carl and Dan, putting Al in apartment 4. But since hypothesis 2 is false, Carl must live east of Al. Therefore, conclusion 3 is true.
Response:
Let the four apartments be numbered 1 (west) to 4 (east).  
Write A, B, C, D for the apartments of Al, Ben, Carl, Dan, and let L denote the landlord.

Each of the four given statements has the logical form  

 (hypothesis)  ⇒  (conclusion).

Hence, for every statement at least one of the following is true:

 • the hypothesis is false, or • the conclusion is true.

We examine the four possible choices for L, keeping this rule in mind.

1. Assume L = Al.  
 If Al were in apartment 1, statement 4 would force an impossible “Dan west of everyone” situation;  
 if Al were not in apartment 1, statements 2 and 4 cannot both be made true.  
 Therefore L ≠ Al.

2. Assume L = Dan.  
 Whether Dan is put in apartment 4 (making the conclusion of statement 2 true) or elsewhere
 (making its hypothesis false), statement 4 requires Dan to be west of Al while statement 3
 requires Ben to be adjacent to Dan and statement 1 requires Carl to be adjacent to Ben.
 No ordering of the four people meets all those demands, so L ≠ Dan.

3. Assume L = Ben.  
 If Ben were in apartment 2 (to make statement 4’s conclusion true) the other three statements
 become simultaneously unsatisfiable;  
 if Ben is not in apartment 2, the hypotheses of all four statements must be false,
 forcing Ben to be adjacent to both Dan and Carl while Dan is west of Al and Al is west of Carl.
 No arrangement of the four distinct apartments allows this.  
 Hence L ≠ Ben.

4. Assume L = Carl.  
 To try to falsify statement 3 we would need Ben adjacent to Dan and Carl, which is impossible;
 therefore the safest way to keep statement 3 true is to make its conclusion true:
 place Carl in apartment 3.

 With C = 3 and L = Carl the other statements work out as follows.

 • Statement 1: Carl (3) is adjacent to Ben (choose B = 4), so its hypothesis is false, hence true.  
 • Statement 2: take Al west of Carl (A = 2) so its hypothesis is false, hence true.  
 • Statement 3: its conclusion (Carl landlord in apt 3) is true.  
 • Statement 4: put Dan in the remaining apartment 1; Dan is not east of Al, so the hypothesis of
  statement 4 is false, making that statement true.

 The final arrangement

  Dan 1  Al 2  Carl 3 (landlord)  Ben 4

 satisfies all four implications simultaneously.

Since every other choice for the landlord leads to a contradiction, the only possible landlord is Carl.

Final answer: Carl

Question:
Question: In the following code, each symbol stands for one of five letters.
@ stands for M, O, F, L, or V
$ stands for B, N, R, E, or J
% stands for T, F, B, L, or A
! stands for W, T, S, E, or I
# stands for F, O, A, T, or L
The five letter code word, %$#@!, can be translated into two English words that are opposites. What are the two words?
 Hint: Prepositions
Hint: Prepositions
Human Solution: Above and Below
Response:
We look for two 5-letter English prepositions that are antonyms and whose letters, position by position, are contained in the symbol–letter lists.

Symbol ⇒ allowed letters  
% ⇒ T F B L A  
$ ⇒ B N R E J  
# ⇒ F O A T L  
@ ⇒ M O F L V  
! ⇒ W T S E I  

Because the hint says “Prepositions”, the natural opposite pair to test is  

 ABOVE vs. BELOW  

Check ABOVE (A B O V E):

1. % = A (A is in T F B L A) ✔  
2. $ = B (B is in B N R E J) ✔  
3. # = O (O is in F O A T L) ✔  
4. @ = V (V is in M O F L V) ✔  
5. ! = E (E is in W T S E I) ✔  

All five letters satisfy their respective symbol sets.

Check BELOW (B E L O W):

1. % = B (B is in T F B L A) ✔  
2. $ = E (E is in B N R E J) ✔  
3. # = L (L is in F O A T L) ✔  
4. @ = O (O is in M O F L V) ✔  
5. ! = W (W is in W T S E I) ✔  

Again, every letter fits its symbol’s set.

Since ABOVE and BELOW are direct opposites and both satisfy the coding constraints, they are the required translations.

Final answer: ABOVE and BELOW

Question:
Question: Two friends, Joe and Smoe, were born in May, one in 1932, the other a year later. Each had an antique grandfather clock of which he was extremely proud. Both of the clocks worked fairly well considering their age, but one clock gained ten seconds per hour while the other one lost ten seconds per hour. On a day in January, the two friends set both clocks correctly at 12:00 noon. "Do you realize," asked Joe, "that the next time both of our clocks will show exactly the same time will be on your 47th birthday?" Smoe agreed. Who is older, Joe or Smoe?
 Hint: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again
Hint: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again
Human Solution: To find the answer, we have to find how long it will be before the clocks show the same time again. This is when the slow clock loses six hours, and the fast one gains six hours. This will take 90 days. In 90 days they will come together at 6:00. On a calendar, there are 90 days between noon January 31, and noon May 1 in years with no leap year. If Smoe had been born in 1933, his 47th birthday would have been in 1980, a leap year. This means that Smoe must be older, born in 1932, and the time of this problem is 1979.
Response:
The fast clock gains 10 s / h, the slow clock loses 10 s / h, so the two dials separate at the rate

 20 s per hour  =  (20⁄3600) h per hour  =  1⁄180 hour of dial-time per real hour.

Two dials that start together will look alike again as soon as they differ by exactly 12 h on a 12-hour face.  
Let t be the real time until that happens:

 (1⁄180) t  =  12  ⇒ t  =  12·180  =  2160 h  =  2160⁄24  =  90 days.

Hence the next coincidence of the two clock faces is 90 days after they were set.

The clocks were set “on a day in January”, and the coincidence is to occur on Smoe’s birthday in May.  
Let the setting be on the J-th day of January of a non-leap year.

 January has 31 days, February 28, March 31, April 30.  
 31 + 28 + 31 = 90.

Therefore one must have J = 31; 90 days after 31 January is 1 May.  
(If the year were a leap year the extra day in February would make the 90-day mark fall on 30 April, not in May, so the year cannot be leap.)

Thus the promise refers to noon, 1 May of a non-leap year.  
That year is 47 years after the birth of the friend whose birthday is in question; therefore

 1 May 1979 ––> 47th birthday ––> birth date 1 May 1932.

The friend who turns 47 on that day must be the one born in 1932.  
Joe said, “the next time … will be on your 47th birthday,” addressing Smoe, so Smoe is the one born in 1932.

Hence Smoe is the elder (born May 1932) and Joe is the younger (born May 1933).

Final answer: Smoe is older.

Question:
Question: You have four jugs:
A: 10-liter jug, filled with water
B: 10-liter jug, filled with water
C: 10-liter jug, empty
D:  9-liter jug, empty
Your objective is to end up having 1 liter in any 10-liter jug and 4 liters in 9-liter jug.
You have nothing else at your disposal and you can not measure using eye or shape of jugs.
Also water can only be transferred between jugs and not dumped out from any of the jugs.
 Hint: Not much of a hint, but it can be solved in 20 steps.
Hint: Not much of a hint, but it can be solved in 20 steps.
Human Solution:
If we label jugs as stated in problem , ABCD, with 9-liter jug being D, problem can be solved in 20 steps, as shown below. Each step is shown in one row, where line start with number of step, followed by information from what jug we poured water into what jug, and how much ... ie.   A -> (9) -> D means we poured 9 liters of water from jug A (being 1st 10-liter jug) to jug D (being 9-liter jug). Finally in row we show how much water we have in each jug after performed this step.
---------------------------------
#s  From-Qty-To     A  B  C  D
---------------------------------
0:                =  10 10  0  0
1:  A ->( 9)->  D =   1 10  0  9
2:  D ->( 9)->  C =   1 10  9  0
3:  A ->( 1)->  D =   0 10  9  1
4:  B ->( 8)->  D =   0  2  9  9
5:  D ->( 9)->  A =   9  2  9  0
6:  A ->( 1)->  C =   8  2 10  0
7:  B ->( 2)->  D =   8  0 10  2
8:  C ->( 7)->  D =   8  0  3  9
9:  D ->( 2)->  A =  10  0  3  7
10:  D ->( 7)->  B =  10  7  3  0
11:  A ->( 9)->  D =   1  7  3  9
12:  A ->( 1)->  C =   0  7  4  9
13:  D ->( 9)->  A =   9  7  4  0
14:  A ->( 3)->  B =   6 10  4  0
15:  B ->( 9)->  D =   6  1  4  9
16:  B ->( 1)->  C =   6  0  5  9
17:  D ->( 4)->  A =  10  0  5  5
18:  D ->( 5)->  B =  10  5  5  0
19:  A ->( 9)->  D =   1  5  5  9
20:  D ->( 5)->  B =   1 10  5  4
After 20th step we end up with 1 liter in first 10-liter jug (A), and 4 liters in 9-liter jug (D), as requested in problem.

Question:
Question: Ole Santa's pack held thirty toys
Made by his elfin crew;
And though none made the same amount,
Each elf made more than two.
The elf named Cher made one more Christmas toy
Than the elf who dressed in reds,
But Cher made one less Christmas toy
Than the elf who made the sleds.
Spry Johnny Elf made racing cars;
Five toys were made by Jane.
The elf who dressed in yellow suits
Made each and every train.
The elf who always dressed in green
Made one-third as many as Sue;
Cute Marcia elf was dressed in orange,
And one elf dressed in blue.
The elf who made the spinning tops
Made the most toys of them all.
Another perky smiling elf
Made each and every ball.
Ole Santa's pack held thirty gifts
All tagged for girls and boys.
From the clues that you've been given,
Now guess who made the toys!
 Hint: This puzzle involves five elves dressed in five different colors each making a different toy. Figure out the numbers that fit these conditions and can add up to thirty!
Hint: This puzzle involves five elves dressed in five different colors each making a different toy. Figure out the numbers that fit these conditions and can add up to thirty!
Human Solution:
Cute Marcia was in orange and made seven sleds.
Sue was in blue and made nine spinning tops.
Jane was in red and made five balls.
Spry Johnny was in green and made three racing cars.
Cher was in yellow and made six trains.
Response:
Let 

• the five elves be  Cher, Johnny, Jane, Sue and Marcia  
• the five suit-colours be  red, yellow, green, orange, blue  
• the five toys be  sleds, spinning-tops, racing-cars, trains, balls  
• the five different numbers of toys (each >2) sum to 30.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Determine the only possible set of numbers

Jane made 5 toys, so 5 is one of the numbers.

Because Cher = (red-suited elf)+1 = (sled-making elf)–1, three consecutive
numbers are required.  
Because the green elf made one-third of Sue’s total, the
pair (green, Sue) must be (x, 3x).

With five different integers >2, the only way to have both a triple of
consecutive numbers and a (x, 3x) pair that still sum to 30 is

  3 , 5 , 6 , 7 , 9

(check quickly: 3+5+6+7+9 = 30).

Hence  
green-suited elf = 3  and  Sue = 9 (the largest).  
Since the spinner made the most toys, Sue made the spinning-tops.

The triple of consecutive numbers must therefore be 5, 6, 7, giving

 red-suited elf = 5, Cher = 6, sled-maker = 7.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Place the remaining fixed facts

• Johnny made racing cars – he must be the elf with 3 or 7 (5 and 6 are
already fixed, 9 belongs to Sue).  
 If Johnny had 7 we would have both “sleds” and “racing cars” with the
same elf, impossible.  
 Therefore Johnny has 3 toys and is the green-suited elf.

• The yellow-suited elf made the trains.  
 The only unused toy/number pair that is not yet fixed is
(6 toys) → Cher, or (7 toys) → the sled-maker.  
 But the sled-maker is already assigned “sleds”, so the yellow suit must
belong to Cher.  
 Hence Cher (6 toys) wore yellow and made the trains.

• Marcia is the only elf whose colour is given (orange), so Marcia
must be the sled-maker with 7 toys.

• The remaining unassigned toy is “balls”; the only elf still without a
toy is Jane.  Thus Jane made the balls.

• The only colour still unused is blue; it therefore belongs to Sue.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Complete chart

Elf   Colour  Toys made  Number  
Johnny  green  racing cars  3  
Jane   red   balls    5  
Cher   yellow  trains    6  
Marcia  orange  sleds    7  
Sue    blue   spinning-tops 9  

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Verification

• Totals are 3,5,6,7,9 (all >2 and sum to 30).  
• Cher = red +1 = 6 = 5+1 and Cher = sleds–1 = 7–1.  
• Green elf (Johnny) has 3, exactly one-third of Sue’s 9.  
• Spinner (Sue) has the largest number.  
• Yellow elf (Cher) made trains; Marcia is orange; one elf (Sue) is blue.  
• All toys, colours and numbers are distinct.

All clues are satisfied.

Final answer:  
Johnny, dressed in green, made 3 racing-cars;  
Jane, dressed in red, made 5 balls;  
Cher, dressed in yellow, made 6 trains;  
Marcia, dressed in orange, made 7 sleds;  
Sue, dressed in blue, made 9 spinning-tops.

Question:
Question: You are back on the same game show with four other contestants. You didn't realise last time that the winner gets another appearance on the show! You now have another chance to win half a million dollars and become a millionaire! The objective is to crack the combination of the safe using the clues. The first person to do so will win $500,000.
The safe combination looks like this:
??-??-??-??
A digit can be used more than once in the code, and there are no zeroes.
Here are the clues:
1. When adding the first number of the third set with the second number of the second set, you will get a number below 8.
2. The only digits not used in the code are 5 and 7.
3. When adding the two digits of the first set together, you will not get 10.
4. If you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed.
5. No set has a number above 90.
6. The product of both the digits in the first set is below 30 but above 20.
7. One of the number sets is 66.
8. There is only one 8 in the combination, and it is in the last set.
Now, get cracking!

 Hint: ??-??-66-??
Human Solution:
The set is 39-21-66-48.
First of all, the second clue tells you there are no 5's or 7's in the combination.
Now we go to the fourth clue. It tells you that if you multiply the second set by 4, you will get the fourth set reversed. There are only a few numbers that will satisfy this:
11, 12, 16, 21, 22, 23 and 24.
Now we skip down to clue 8, which tells us there is one 8 only, and it is in the last set. It could either be the first digit or the second digit.
However, this eliminates these numbers from being in the second set: 11, 16, 23 and 24. Now, only 12, 21 and 22 are the possibilities for being in the second set.
Now, let's look at clue 7. This tells us that 66 is one of the four number sets. We know it can't be in the second, or fourth, and since clue six tells us the product of the two numbers in the first set ranges from 21-29, 66 must go in the third set.
??-??-66-??
Now we must look at the first clue. The first number of the third set (6) plus the second number of the second set will get a number below 8. This means it cannot be 12 or 22, because they would both total 8. This means that the second set of numbers is 21. Making good progress!
??-21-66-??
Now, we come back to clue 4 which tells us the second set multiplied by 4 equals the fourth set reversed. 21 multiplied by 4 is 84, which when reversed is 48!
??-21-66-48
Now, we come back to clue 6, which tells us the product of the digits in the first set is above 20 but below 30. These are the only numbers that satisfy that condition - and remember, no 5's, 7's or 8's are left in the combination:
39 (3 * 9 = 27)
46 (4 * 6 = 24)
64 (6 * 4 = 24)
93 (9 * 3 = 27)
Now, we look at clue 5. This eliminates 93. Now, come to clue 3. This tells us the sum of the two digits in the first set does not equal 10. This eliminates 46 and 64. The only number left is.... 39!
Now you have your answer;
39-21-66-48
Congratulations!!! You won, again!! You are over the moon! You have become the first millionaire in five generations of your family history!!
Response: Final answer: 39-21-66-48

Question:
Question: A warden at a prison decides to give some prisoners a chance to escape by working together to solve a puzzle. He prepares a colored hat for every one of them and tells them the rules. The hats can be either black or white and will be placed on everyone's head.  The prisoners will get a chance to discuss a strategy together, which they will all follow, then they will be marched out into a large room where they will see everybody else's hat color. Each prisoner will then simultaneously guess which of the two hat colors they have. If every one of them is right, or every one of them is wrong, they will all go free. However, the prisoners will not be allowed to communicate in any way during this process. Also, the warden will hear their strategy and place hats any way he can to prevent them from going free. What strategy do they use to escape?
 Hint: Think about it for two people and then three people. What will be the difference between what a white hatted person sees and a black hatted person sees?
Hint: Think about it for two people and then three people. What will be the difference between what a white hatted person sees and a black hatted person sees?
Human Solution: Every prisoner should count up how many black hats they see. If they count an odd number of black hats, they say that they have a black hat. If they count an even number of black hats, then they say that they have a white hat.
Response:
Strategy agreed upon before the hats are put on  

1. Every prisoner will, after the hats are placed, silently count how many WHITE hats he can see on the other prisoners.  
2. If he sees an EVEN number of white hats he will announce “WHITE”.  
   If he sees an ODD number of white hats he will announce “BLACK”.

Why this always liberates them

Let W be the (unknown) total number of white hats actually on all prisoners, and let wi be 1 if prisoner i’s own hat is white and 0 if it is black.

Prisoner i sees W – wi white hats, so the parity he sees is  
(W – wi) (mod 2) = (W mod 2) – wi (mod 2).

Case 1.  W is ODD (W mod 2 = 1).  
 • If prisoner i wears a white hat (wi=1) he sees an EVEN number of white hats.  
   By the rule he says “WHITE”, which is correct.  
 • If prisoner i wears a black hat (wi=0) he sees an ODD number of white hats.  
   He therefore says “BLACK”, which is also correct.  
 Hence every single prisoner is correct; they go free.

Case 2.  W is EVEN (W mod 2 = 0).  
 • If prisoner i wears a white hat (wi=1) he sees an ODD number of white hats.  
   He therefore says “BLACK”, which is wrong.  
 • If prisoner i wears a black hat (wi=0) he sees an EVEN number of white hats.  
   He therefore says “WHITE”, which is also wrong.  
 Thus every prisoner is wrong; again they go free.

Consequently, no matter how the adversarial warden chooses the hat colors, the prisoners’ answers are either all right (when the total number of white hats is odd) or all wrong (when it is even). This satisfies the warden’s condition, so the entire group of prisoners is guaranteed to win its freedom.

Final answer: Each prisoner counts the white hats he sees; if he sees an even number he guesses “white”, otherwise he guesses “black”. This makes them all simultaneously correct when the total number of white hats is odd and all simultaneously incorrect when it is even, so they are certain to be released.

Question:
Question: Madadian Multi-Squillionaire Sheik Ratelunroll has bought four prestige cars from the Madadian Motor Company (MMC) - The Silver Dream, The Golden Pleasure, The Devine Lightning, and a The Rusting Bucket, - as presents for his sons' birthdays, all of which are next week (strange things like this happen in Madadia all the time). Given the following information, what will each son get?
1, Derek will not get The Golden Pleasure unless Berrick gets The Silver Dream and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
2, Berrick will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Derek gets The Silver Dream.
3, Eric will not get The Devine Lightning unless Derek gets The Golden Pleasure and Berrick gets The Silver Dream.
4, Derek will not get The Silver Dream unless Merick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
5, Berrick will not get The Silver Dream unless Derek gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Rusting Bucket.
6, Derek will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Merick gets The Silver Dream.
7, Merick will not get The Devine Lightning unless Berrick gets The Golden Pleasure and Derek gets The Rusting Bucket.
8, Derek will not get The Rusting Bucket unless Berrick gets The Devine Lightning and Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
9, Merick will not get The Silver Dream unless Eric gets The Golden Pleasure.
 Hint: Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream.
Hint: Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream.
Human Solution:
Starting with the simplest requirement, #9, assume that Eric does in fact get The Golden Pleasure, then Merick gets The Silver Dream. This leaves The Rusting Bucket and The Devine Lightning for Berrick and Derek. Going to rule #8, Eric already has The Golden Pleasure, so if Berrick gets The Devine Lightning, then Derek can have The Rusting Bucket. This gives us the following that complies with rules 8 & 9:
Eric = The Golden Pleasure
Merick = The Silver Dream
Berrick = The Devine Lightning
Derek = The Rusting Bucket
Now, to see if this works, just check it out against rules 1 through 7, where you'll find no rules are violated and everyone's happy except Derek who got stuck with The Rusting Bucket.
Response:
Step 1 – Show that Derek cannot receive three of the four cars.

(a) Suppose Derek were to get the Golden Pleasure.  
     By (1) this would force Berrick → Silver Dream and Eric → Rusting Bucket.  
     But then Berrick = Silver Dream triggers (5), which in turn requires  
     Derek → Devine Lightning (and Eric → Rusting Bucket).  
     Derek would have to hold both Golden Pleasure and Devine Lightning – impossible.  
     Hence Derek cannot get the Golden Pleasure.

(b) Suppose Derek were to get the Silver Dream.  
     By (4) this would force Merick → Devine Lightning and Eric → Rusting Bucket.  
     Merick = Devine Lightning then activates (7), which requires  
     Berrick → Golden Pleasure and Derek → Rusting Bucket.  
     Derek would have to hold both Silver Dream and Rusting Bucket – impossible.  
     Hence Derek cannot get the Silver Dream.

(c) Suppose Derek were to get the Devine Lightning.  
     By (6) this would force Berrick → Golden Pleasure and Merick → Silver Dream.  
     Merick = Silver Dream now triggers (9), which requires Eric → Golden Pleasure.  
     But the Golden Pleasure would already be in Berrick’s hands, so two sons would
     share the same car – impossible.  
     Hence Derek cannot get the Devine Lightning.

Since Derek must receive exactly one car, the only remaining possibility is

     Derek → Rusting Bucket.

Step 2 – Consequences of Derek having the Rusting Bucket.

With Derek = Rusting Bucket, rule (8) applies:

     Derek → Rusting Bucket  ⇒  Berrick → Devine Lightning  and  Eric → Golden Pleasure.

Step 3 – Allocate the last unassigned car.

The Silver Dream is now the only car still unallocated, so it must go to the unassigned son:

     Merick → Silver Dream.

Step 4 – Verify all rules.

• (1) Derek is not getting Golden Pleasure – no condition to check.  
• (2) Berrick is not getting Rusting Bucket – no condition.  
• (3) Eric is not getting Devine Lightning – no condition.  
• (4) Derek is not getting Silver Dream – no condition.  
• (5) Berrick is not getting Silver Dream – no condition.  
• (6) Derek is not getting Devine Lightning – no condition.  
• (7) Merick is not getting Devine Lightning – no condition.  
• (8) Derek is getting Rusting Bucket and indeed Berrick = Devine Lightning, Eric = Golden Pleasure.  
• (9) Merick is getting Silver Dream and indeed Eric = Golden Pleasure.

Every implication is satisfied and each car is assigned to exactly one son.

Final answer:  
Derek – Rusting Bucket  
Berrick – Devine Lightning  
Merick – Silver Dream  
Eric – Golden Pleasure

Question:
Question: Thirty fans hire a bus to attend a football game. On the way to the stadium, they realize that exactly half of them are fans of one team and the other half are fans of the other team. With still some way to go before reaching the stadium, the bus develops mechanical problems and the driver announces to his passengers that the only way to continue the journey is for half of them to get out and walk. There is a huge fight that doesn't stop until the driver speaks to them again and suggests a way of selecting the passengers who are to get off the bus.
"All of you," he said, "get into a big circle. When you are ready, beginning at this spot, I'll count nine people clockwise. The ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. Then I'll count another nine starting from where I stopped, and the ninth person leaves the circle and continues on foot. And so on until fifteen people have left the circle."
Suppose that you are one of the fans. How should you arrange all the other fans of your team so that none of them will have to leave?
 Hint: Just keep counting in circles and see where you each spot lands
Hint: Just keep counting in circles and see where you each spot lands
Human Solution: If the two teams are A and B and you are a supporter of team A and don't want any of your fellow supporters to end up walking to the stadium, organize them in a circle starting at the point where the driver starts and reading clockwise as follows: A, A, A, A, B, B, B, B, B, A, A, B, A, A, A, B, A, B, B, A, A, B, B, B, A, B, B, A, A, B.
Response:
Label the places in the circle 1,2,…,30 clockwise and let the driver begin his count with the person standing in place 1 (you may take that place yourself).  
Starting with that place, eliminate every 9-th person (Josephus problem with n = 30, k = 9) until 15 persons have been eliminated.  
Doing the count carefully gives the order in which the first 15 places are eliminated:

1st 9    6th 26  11th 24  
2nd 18   7th 7   12th 8  
3rd 27   8th 19  13th 22  
4th 6    9th 30  14th 5  
5th 16  10th 12  15th 23

Hence the fifteen places that have to leave are  

5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 12, 16, 18, 19, 22, 23, 24, 26, 27, 30.

Put every supporter of the other team in exactly these fifteen places and put the members of your own party in the remaining fifteen places

1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 20, 21, 25, 28, 29.

When the driver now counts off every 9-th person, all of the rival fans will be the ones forced to leave while every one of your team’s supporters (including you in place 1) will stay on the bus.

Final answer: Place your own team’s fans in positions 1, 2, 3, 4, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 20, 21, 25, 28 and 29 (you can stand in position 1). Put the other team’s fans in the remaining positions; then only the other team’s fans will be the fifteen people who have to get off.

Question:
Question: It appears that you have angered the spirit of Halloween by failing to revere the Great Pumpkin, and now a curse has befallen you.  On the walkway to your house is a Ward of Seven Jack O'Lanterns arranged in a circle.  If midnight comes and any of the seven are still lit, a dark reaper and seven dark horses with seven dark riders shall visit thy abode.  They shall surround thy domicile and, while circling it, they will proceed to pelt thy dwelling with eggs and cream of shaving.  And come morn there will be a great mess to be reckoned with.  Verily.  So you better get those lanterns out.
You quickly discover something odd about these lanterns.  When you blow out the first one, the lanterns on either side extinguish as well!  But there is more.  If you blow out a lantern adjacent to one that is extinguished, the extinguished one(s) will relight.  It seems that blowing on any lantern will change the state of three - the one you blew on and its two neighbors.  Finally, you can blow on an extinguished lantern and it will relight, and its neighbors will light/extinguish as applicable.  After trying once and finding all seven lit again, you decide, being the excellent puzzler, you sit down and examine this closer.  But hurry, I hear the beating of many hooves...
 Hint: If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.
Hint: If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.
Human Solution:
If you examine the setup carefully, you'll note a number of facts which make the puzzle easier to solve by deduction.  First, blowing on a lantern is a commutative property; blowing on lanterns 1, 5, then 3 is the same as blowing on 3, then 1, and then 5.  No matter what order the lanterns are blown on, if the same lanterns are blown on the same number of times, the result won't change.  For that reason, blowing on a lantern twice is as good as not blowing on it at all.  And three times is as good as one time. So, it seems that it should be able to be done in seven steps or less.
What else can we tell about the solution?  Since each operation changes the state of three lanterns, and there are 7 lanterns, and each lantern must change its state an odd number of times, it's a safe bet that there will need to be an odd number of steps.  We can easily see it can't be done in 1 or 3 steps, so it must be 5 or 7.  Trying 5 steps comes up with 3 different patterns that are not symmetrical and fail to leave all lanterns extinguished.  So that leaves 7 steps and to your surprise, based on the commutative property, the easiest solution is to blow on each one in order!  So doing this, the Great Pumpkin has decided to give you a treat for figuring this out and you find all seven lanterns full of candy the next morning!  Congratulations!
Response:
Let the seven lanterns be numbered 1,2,3,4,5,6,7 clockwise round the circle (lantern 7 is next to 1).

1.  What “blowing on a lantern’’ means  
   • Blowing on lantern k toggles the states of k and its two neighbours,  
     i.e. lanterns k‒1, k, k+1 (indices taken mod 7).  
   • Doing the same blow twice restores the three lanterns to their
     previous condition, so only the parity (even/odd) of the blows on
     each lantern matters.  
   • Because the blows commute, we may assume that each lantern is blown
     either 0 or 1 time, and the order is irrelevant.

Let  
   x₁,x₂,…,x₇  ∈{0,1}  (mod 2)  
denote whether we blow once (1) or not at all (0) on lanterns 1,…,7.

2.  The seven equations  
A lantern is finally out (state 0) iff it was initially lit (state 1)
and is toggled an odd number of times.  
For lantern 1 we therefore need

      1 + x₇ + x₁ + x₂  = 0   (mod 2).                (E₁)

Rotating this relation round the circle gives the complete system

      x₇ + x₁ + x₂ = 1      (E₁)
      x₁ + x₂ + x₃ = 1      (E₂)
      x₂ + x₃ + x₄ = 1      (E₃)
      x₃ + x₄ + x₅ = 1      (E₄)
      x₄ + x₅ + x₆ = 1      (E₅)
      x₅ + x₆ + x₇ = 1      (E₆)
      x₆ + x₇ + x₁ = 1      (E₇)

3.  Solving the system (all arithmetic mod 2)

   Subtract E₁ from E₂:  (x₁+x₂+x₃)+(x₇+x₁+x₂)=x₃+x₇=0  ⇒  x₃=x₇.  
   Subtract E₂ from E₃:  x₄+x₁=0  ⇒  x₄=x₁.  
   Subtract E₃ from E₄:  x₅+x₂=0  ⇒  x₅=x₂.  
   Subtract E₄ from E₅:  x₆+x₃=0  ⇒  x₆=x₃.  
   Subtract E₅ from E₆:  x₇+x₄=0  ⇒  x₇=x₄.  
   Subtract E₆ from E₇:  x₁+x₅=0  ⇒  x₁=x₅.

   Chaining these equalities gives

          x₁ = x₂ = x₃ = x₄ = x₅ = x₆ = x₇.

   Call their common value x.

   Insert into any equation, say E₁:

          x + x + x = 1  ⇒  3x = 1  ⇒  x = 1  (since 3 ≡ 1 mod 2).

   Hence every x_k equals 1.

4.  Interpretation  
Blow once on every lantern, i.e. on 1,2,3,4,5,6,7 (in any order).
Each lantern is then toggled three times (by itself and its two
neighbours), which is an odd number, so every lantern finishes in the
state opposite to its initial one – namely, extinguished.

5.  Uniqueness  
Because the linear system has the single solution x₁=…=x₇=1, any other
pattern of blows (different parities) must leave at least one lantern
still lit. Thus blowing on all seven lanterns once each is both
sufficient and necessary.

Final answer: Blow once on every one of the seven lanterns (in any order); afterwards they will all be out.

Question:
Question: Every day from Monday through Sunday in this week, Mr. Peter picks two shirts from the five colours red, blue, yellow, green and black. Peter follows the rules:
1. Peter doesn't use the same combination on two days of this week.
2. Peter doesn't use the same colour on two consecutive days of this week.
3. Peter uses some colour on four days.
4. Peter uses blue and black on Monday.
5. Peter uses green on Thursday.
6. Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday.
7. Peter doesn't combine red with black.
What colours does Peter use on Saturday?
 Hint: Start from rules 2 and 3
Hint: Start from rules 2 and 3
Human Solution:
From rules 2 and 3, Peter must use one colour on Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, which can be blue or black.
If it's black, from rules 1 and 4, Peter must combine black with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, but rule 7 disallows combining black with red.
Therefore, it's blue, and Peter must combine blue with red, yellow and green on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday. From rule 5, Peter uses green on Thursday, he can't use green on Wednesday or Friday, and only on Sunday.
From rule 6, Peter doesn't use yellow on Friday, and he can only use red on Friday and yellow on Wednesday.
Since Peter uses blue, red and green on Friday and Sunday, from rule 2, he can only use black and yellow on Saturday.
Response: Final answer: yellow and black

Question:
Question: At the Christmas party of the "Sweaty Chef" kebab shop, the owner Mr Juan, took note of how many people were present. Although he was a bit tipsy when he made his note, and thus made a mistake.  His notes were as follows:-
1, There were 9 men and children.
2, There were 2 more women than children.
3, The number of different man-woman couples possible was 24. Note that if there were 7 men and 5 women, then there would have been 35 man-woman couples possible.
Also, of the three groups - men, women and children - at the party:
4, There were 4 of one group.
5, There were 6 of one group.
6, There were 8 of one group.
Exactly one of the above 6 statements is false.
Can you tell which one is false? Also, how many men, women and children are there at the party?
 Hint: Can 4,5,6 all be true at the same time?
Hint: Can 4,5,6 all be true at the same time?
Human Solution:
Statement (4) is false. There are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children.
Assume that Statements (4), (5) and (6) are all true. Then, Statement (1) is false. But then Statement (2) and (3) both can not be true. Thus, contradictory to the fact that exactly one statement is false.
So Statement (4) or Statement (5) or Statement (6) is false. Also, Statements (1), (2) and (3) all are true.
From (1) and (2), there are 11 men and women. Then from (3), there are 2 possible cases - either there are 8 men and 3 women or there are 3 men and 8 women.
If there are 8 men and 3 women, then there is 1 child. Then Statements (4) and (5) both are false, which is not possible.
Hence, there are 3 men, 8 women and 6 children. Statement (4) is false.
Response:
Let  

m = number of men  
w = number of women  
c = number of children  

Interpret the six notes.

1. “There were 9 men and children’’  ⇒ m + c = 9  
2. “There were 2 more women than children’’ ⇒ w = c + 2  
3. “The number of different man-woman couples was 24’’ ⇒ m w = 24  

Notes 4, 5, 6 each name a group size (4, 6, 8).  
If all three of them were true, the three sizes would have to be 4, 6, 8 simultaneously; but then m + c could not be 9, so at least one of 4–6 must be the false note.  
Therefore notes 1, 2, 3 must all be true.

Solve the true equations (1)–(3).

From (2): w = c + 2  
From (1): m = 9 – c  

Substitute these into (3):

(9 – c)(c + 2) = 24  
–c² + 7c + 18 = 24  
c² – 7c + 6 = 0  
(c – 6)(c – 1) = 0  ⇒ c = 6  or c = 1.

Case 1: c = 6  
 w = 8, m = 3  
 Group sizes: 3, 6, 8.  
 • “There were 4 of one group’’ is false.  
 • “There were 6 of one group’’ is true.  
 • “There were 8 of one group’’ is true.  
Exactly one note (the 4-statement) is false, as required.

Case 2: c = 1  
 w = 3, m = 8  
 Group sizes: 1, 3, 8.  
 Both the 4-statement and the 6-statement are false, giving two false notes, which is not allowed.

Hence Case 1 is the only admissible situation.

So the mistaken note is statement 4 (“There were 4 of one group’’), and the actual attendance is:

men = 3, women = 8, children = 6.

Final answer: statement 4 is the false one; there were 3 men, 8 women, and 6 children.

Question:
Question: Write on a piece of paper a 5x5 letter square using the alphabet, minus the letter Q, where A is in the upper left-hand corner and Z is in the lower right-hand corner.  After you have done this, can you tell me which letter comes just above the letter which comes between the letter just before the letter just below B and the letter just before the letter just above Y?
 Hint: One step at a time
Hint: One step at a time
Human Solution:
The letter is G.
The two letters to initially find are F & S. The letter above the one which is between them is G.
Response:
We first construct the required 5 × 5 square by writing the alphabet in ordinary order, omitting the single letter Q.

A  B  C  D  E  
F  G  H  I  J  
K  L  M  N  O  
P  R  S  T  U  
V  W  X  Y  Z  

(Thus A is indeed in the upper-left corner and Z in the lower-right.)

Now decode the chain of directions, strictly one step at a time.

1.  Start with B (row 1, column 2).  
2.  “The letter just below B” is G (row 2, column 2).  
3.  “The letter just before” that (one space to the left in the same row) is F (row 2, column 1).  
   →  Call this letter F our first reference letter.

4.  Start again, now with Y (row 5, column 4).  
5.  “The letter just above Y” is T (row 4, column 4).  
6.  “The letter just before” that is S (row 4, column 3).  
   →  Call this letter S our second reference letter.

7.  We need “the letter which comes between F and S.”  
    In the square, F is at (2, 1) and S at (4, 3); the only cell lying directly between them on the straight diagonal is (3, 2), which contains L.  
   →  Thus the “between” letter is L.

8.  Finally, we want “the letter which comes just above” that L.  
    L is at (3, 2); the cell directly above it, (2, 2), contains G.

Therefore the required letter is G.

Final answer: G

Question:
Question: Kevin's class picture has 28 photos arranged in a 7 x 4 grid.  The photos in the top row are numbered 1 through 7 from left to right, with the photos in the remaining rows similarly numbered.  Given the following clues (bordering includes horizontal, vertical, and diagonal), where is Kevin's picture?
X X X X X X X (1 - 7)
X X X X X X X (8 - 14)
X X X X X X X (15 - 21)
X X X X X X X (22 - 28)
1) There are 11 boys and 17 girls.
2) No boy is next to another boy horizontally or vertically.
3) There are no more than three boys in each row.
4) One column has only girls.
5) Three boys are not along the edge of the picture.
6) The second boy is at an odd position.
7) The range of the boys' positions is 24.
8) The median of the boys' positions is 12 or 13 or 14.
9) There are boys in two corners.
10) Kevin occupies an even position, and is the only boy who borders a unique number of girls.
 Hint: There are five boys prior to the median, meaning that there are three boys in each of the first two rows.
Hint: There are five boys prior to the median, meaning that there are three boys in each of the first two rows.
Human Solution:
A) There are five boys prior to the median, meaning that there are three boys in each of the first two rows.  If the first boy is at location 4, then there could only be two boys in the first row.  The first boy must be located before position 4, therefore a girl must occupy: 28 (clue 7).  The second boy can not be at position 4 (clue 6).  The earliest position that the third boy could occupy is position 5.  Therefore, a girl must occupy: 4.
B) If boys are at positions 1 (a corner) and 25 (clue 7), then a boy would have to be at either position 7 or 22 (clue 9).  In either case, more than three boys would not be along the edge of the picture, violating clue 5.  Therefore, a girl must occupy: 1.  Boys must occupy: 7 and 22 (clue 9).  Girls must occupy: 6, 14, 15, and 23.
C) For three boys to be in the first row, the second boy must occupy: 5 (which also satisfies clue 6).  A girl must occupy 12.  Per clue 8, a boy must occupy: 13.  A girl must occupy: 20.  To avoid violating clue 5, boys must occupy: 8 and 21.  A girl must occupy: 9.
D) Clues 8 and 9 have now been satisfied, and 16 of the 28 positions have been filled.  To satisfy clues 1 through 7, the last 12 positions can be filled in four different ways.  However, only one of those ways will satisfy clue 10.  In the three ways that do not work, the boy that borders a unique number of girls is located at an odd position.
Step A       Step B       Step C       Step D
xxxGxxx      GxxGxGB      GxxGBGB      GBGGBGB
xxxxxxx      xxxxxxG      BGxxGBG      BGBGGBG
xxxxxxx      Gxxxxxx      GxxxxGB      GBGGGGB
xxxxxxG      BGxxxxG      BGxxxxG      BGBGBGG
The boys in the first row border (3, 4, 2) girls.
The boys in the second row border (3, 6, 5) girls.
The boys in the third row border (4, 4) girls.
The boys in the fourth row border (2, 4, 5) girls.
The only boy that borders a unique number of girls is the boy who borders six girls, which is at position 10.  Kevin is at position 10.

Question:
Question: Consider a grid of size 4 x 4 (i.e. sixteen squares), where all squares should get a color. The colored grid should meet the following conditions:
4 squares should be colored blue,
3 squares should be colored red,
3 squares should be colored white,
3 squares should be colored green,
3 squares should be colored yellow, and
How can these squares be arranged so that no color appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line?
 Hint: Start by placing the blues.
Hint: Start by placing the blues.
Human Solution:
There are multiple possible answers. Just check that the conditions in the original problem statement hold: 
4 squares should be colored blue,
3 squares should be colored red,
3 squares should be colored white,
3 squares should be colored green,
3 squares should be colored yellow, and
How can these squares be arranged so that no color appears more than once in any horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line?

One possible arrangement:
W B G R
R Y W B
B G R Y
Y W B G
Response:
One possible arrangement is  

               C1   C2   C3   C4
        R1 :   R    B    W    Y
        R2 :   Y    G    R    B
        R3 :   B    W    Y    G
        R4 :   G    R    B    W

(Here R = red, B = blue, W = white, G = green, Y = yellow.)

Verification  

1. Numbers of squares  
 Blue = 4 (1,2), (2,4), (3,1), (4,3)  
 Red  = 3 (1,1), (2,3), (4,2)  
 White= 3 (1,3), (3,2), (4,4)  
 Green= 3 (2,2), (3,4), (4,1)  
 Yellow=3 (1,4), (2,1), (3,3)

2. Rows and columns  
Every row and every column contains each color at most once.

3. Diagonals  
For every NW-SE diagonal (constant “row − column”) and every NE-SW diagonal
(constant “row + column”) each color occurs at most once; e.g. the main
diagonal (1,1)(2,2)(3,3)(4,4) contains R,G,Y,W – all different, and so on for
every other diagonal.

Hence the grid satisfies all the required conditions.

Final answer:  

Row 1 = Red Blue White Yellow  
Row 2 = Yellow Green Red Blue  
Row 3 = Blue White Yellow Green  
Row 4 = Green Red Blue White

Question:
Question: I woke up late that morning to welcome a bright sunny day after a long and hectic week. It was a holiday and I was determined to spend the day playing cards with my friend Tweeto. Tweeto's favorite card game was the Romankachi card game.
The rules of the game are as follows :-
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
We started off with 5 cards each and I served in the first round.
At the end of three rounds if I had exactly 4 cards then which of the following statements must be true:-
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
NOTE: Out of the given set of 3 statements, it is not necessary that one and only one statement is true. One or more statements may be true.
 Hint: First, think about what possible results could lead to you having 4 cards?
Hint: First, think about what possible results could lead to you having 4 cards?
Human Solution:
Statements A and C must be true.
The rules of the Romankachi card game are given below.
1) One person 'serves' and the other 'receives' cards in each round.
2) The person who serves cards in the round gains 2 cards if he wins the round and loses only 1 card if he loses the round.
3) On the other hand, the person who receives cards in the round, gains only 1 card if he wins the round and loses 2 cards if he loses the round.
4) Finally the person who wins in one round, serves in the next round.
5) The game is stopped when a player loses all his cards.
The given statements are
A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.
B) I must have won the first round.
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.
Since we started the card game with 5 cards each and I started of the first round, at the end of three rounds I can have 4 cards due to any one of the following two results.
First Result :
I served in the first round and won. Hence I served in the second round but lost. Tweeto served in the third round and again I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round      Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    7           3
Round 2    6           4
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is true here because I won the first round.
Second Result :
I served in the first round and lost. Hence Tweeto served in the second round but he lost. I served in the third round and I lost thus ending up with 4 cards.
The number of cards with me and Tweeto is tabulated below.
Round     Me    Tweeto
Initially     5           5
Round 1    4           6
Round 2    5           5
Round 3    4           6
Applying the given statements  to the above table, we can observe that statements A and C are true since Tweeto won exactly two rounds and Tweeto won the third round. Statement B is false here because I lost the first round.
Hence it is clear from both the results that statements A and C must be true for me to end up with 4 cards at the end of three rounds.
Response:
Let M denote me and T denote Tweeto.  
At the start we each have 5 cards and I (M) serve the first round.

Effect of one round  
 • If the server wins he gains 2 cards, receiver loses 2.  
 • If the receiver wins he gains 1 card, server loses 1.  
Hence each round merely moves cards from one player to the other; the total number of cards (10) is unchanged.

Let Δ be my change in cards in a round.

 Serving   Receiving  
 win  Δ = +2  win  Δ = +1  
 lose Δ = –1  lose Δ = –2

After three rounds I have 4 cards, i.e. a net change of –1 (because 5 → 4).

Round 1: I am the server.

─────────────────
1. I win round 1  
 Then I serve round 2.

 Round 2 possibilities
 a) I win Δ = +2 (totally impossible: I would already have 9 cards and T only 1, so the game would have ended or the next loss is impossible).  
 b) I lose Δ = –1, so after two rounds my net change is +1 (I have 6 cards).  
  T now serves round 3.  
  Round 3  
   • T wins (I lose as receiver): Δ = –2 ⇒ total change +1 – 2 = –1.  
   • I win: Δ = +1 ⇒ total change +1 + 1 = +2 (gives me 7 cards).  
  Only “T wins round 3’’ works.  
 Winners: M, T, T.

2. T wins round 1  
 I lose as server: Δ = –1 (I now have 4 cards).  
 T serves round 2.

 Round 2 possibilities  
 a) T wins (I lose as receiver): Δ = –2 ⇒ total –3 (I would have 2 cards; cannot be raised to 4 in one round).  
 b) I win (receiver): Δ = +1 ⇒ total 0 (I am back at 5). I now serve round 3.  
  Round 3  
   • I win (server): Δ = +2 ⇒ total +2.  
   • T wins (I lose as server): Δ = –1 ⇒ total –1, giving me 4 cards.  
  Only “T wins round 3’’ works.  
 Winners: T, M, T.

─────────────────
Thus there are exactly two possible sequences of winners:

 (1) M, T, T    (2) T, M, T

Both sequences have the following common facts:

• Tweeto wins exactly two of the three rounds.  
• Tweeto wins the third round.

Whether I win the first round depends on which of the two sequences occurs; it is not forced.

Therefore the statements that must be true are:

A) Tweeto must have won exactly two rounds.  
C) Tweeto must have won the third round.

Statement B is not necessarily true.

Final answer: A and C

Question:
Question: Phil Fegit was sitting in his bedroom watching the torrential rain pour down on his home town of MADADIA.  The water had caused floods throughout the town and water over six feet deep had forced people to abandon the downstairs of their homes and they had to retreat to the upstairs rooms. The yearly Kebab harvest had been washed away as the downpour had continued unabated for a full month.
